scenario_description: SEC enforcement investigation into insider trading at a mid-cap pharmaceutical company. A junior analyst tipped the SEC that executives traded ahead of a failed FDA trial. Four entities navigate the investigation with structurally enforced information barriers: the SEC enforcement attorney builds a case through formal channels only (subpoenas, depositions, trading records); the company general counsel faces conflicting duties to the board and implicated executives; the whistleblower holds direct knowledge but fears retaliation; and outside defense counsel represents the implicated VP with privileged communications the SEC cannot access. Knowledge provenance tracks exactly who knew about material non-public information (the Phase III trial failure) and when, which is the legal definition of insider trading liability.

patch.name: SEC Insider Trading Investigation
patch.author: timepoint-daedalus
patch.description: SEC enforcement investigation with information barriers, discovery sequencing, and knowledge provenance tracking material non-public information flow

sec_attorney_walsh.role: SEC Division of Enforcement senior attorney. Builds case through formal channels: subpoenas, document requests, depositions. Cannot access privileged defense communications.

general_counsel_park.role: Company general counsel. Duty to cooperate with SEC investigation while protecting the company. Learned about the trading pattern from internal audit before the SEC inquiry. Conflicting loyalties.

whistleblower_chen.role: Junior clinical data analyst. Overheard VP discussing the Phase III failure before public announcement, then observed VP's broker call. Filed anonymous SEC tip. Identity protected by Dodd-Frank but fears retaliation.

defense_counsel_morrison.role: Outside white-collar defense attorney representing the implicated VP. Has attorney-client privileged knowledge of VP's actual trading rationale. Must decide cooperation vs. contest strategy.

knowledge_provenance_emphasis.description: This template is designed to exercise M3 knowledge provenance in a securities law context. The central legal question — who possessed material non-public information (MNPI) and when — maps directly to exposure event tracking.
information_barriers: SEC attorney cannot access attorney-client privileged communications between VP and defense counsel
General counsel knows about internal audit flag but has not disclosed it to SEC yet
Whistleblower identity is sealed — SEC knows content of tip but other entities do not know the source
Defense counsel has privileged knowledge of VP's actual intent that no other entity can access
Judge (if case escalates) only sees formally filed pleadings and admitted evidence

investigation_timeline.event: SEC receives anonymous tip via Dodd-Frank portal. Opens preliminary inquiry. Pulls public trading records. Company unaware of investigation.
SEC issues formal subpoena to company for trading records and communications. General counsel learns of investigation, must decide what to disclose from internal audit. Defense counsel retained.
Document production reveals suspicious email chain. SEC requests whistleblower deposition (identity still sealed). Defense counsel files motion to quash on privilege grounds.
Depositions conducted. General counsel's conflicting loyalty tested — board demands cooperation, VP demands protection. Key evidence surfaces from IT forensics.
SEC presents settlement offer vs. enforcement action. Defense counsel must advise: settle (admit liability, pay fine) or contest (risk trial). Whistleblower's Dodd-Frank bounty depends on outcome.

key_legal_concepts: Material Non-Public Information (MNPI): Information not yet public that a reasonable investor would consider important
Tipper-tippee liability: Both the source and recipient of MNPI can be liable
Attorney-client privilege: Communications between VP and defense counsel are protected
Upjohn warning: General counsel must clarify they represent the company, not individual executives
